intro: Sida gossweileri, commonly known as the desert mallow, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a herbaceous annual or perennial plant that typically grows in sandy or rocky soils. The plant produces small, pink or purple flowers that bloom in summer, and its leaves are ovate with a hairy texture. Sida gossweileri is adapted to withstand drought conditions and has a deep root system for water absorption. It is often found in disturbed habitats and can thrive in low-nutrient environments.
